results.title: Horsham Greyhounds
results.brief_description: Meet the people that work at the greyhound races every Tuesday afternoon at Horsham, in western Victoria. Mostly volunteers, they assist the dogs and their owners from vets checks to wash downs, ensuring that Horsham Greyhounds remains the safest race in Victoria.

results.title: The Gasifier
results.brief_description: Bill Gardner is tackling climate change in his own backyard, with the help of his mates John and Will. Together, these ‘Wimmera men’, located in western Victoria, are investigating the potential of using gasifier technology, which can be used to convert grain into fuel. Rather than being dismissed as ‘crazy’, this initiative has received widespread support from both the government and community.

results.title: Clarrie's Ranch
results.creator_credit: Jessica Scott, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Clarence ‘Clarrie’ Mackley has built his own patch of paradise, a small ranch devoted to Slim Dusty, Elvis and all things country and western. Living by his ethos of ‘do what you wanna do’, Mackley attracts tourists from all over to the world to his colourful place in Horsham, western Victoria.

results.title: At the Foot of the Arapiles
results.brief_description: Meet the business owners and locals who call Natimuk home and wouldn’t want to live anywhere else. Even though locals consider it to be full of ‘climbers’ and ‘arty-types’, they recognise Natimuk, in western Victoria, as an active and diverse community and wouldn’t have it any other way.

results.title: ACMI in the regions: Stories from East Gippsland
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: The towns of Swifts Creek, Omeo, Lakes Entrance, Orbost, Marlo and Cape Conran are quite distinct from each other but all make up the region of East Gippsland, which lies in the south-east of Victoria. In ‘ACMI in the regions: stories from East Gippsland’, locals from each town are interviewed about their lives, their community and what makes living in these towns so special.

results.title: Welcome to Cape Conran
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Have you ever wondered what it’s like to live and work in a National Park? Cape Conran Coastal Park consists of 11,700 hectares of pristine coastal wilderness. Meet Carla and Josh Puglisi who manage the park as well as Mike Irvine; the park ranger, as they talk about the importance of protecting the coastal environment, the rich indigenous history of the area as well as what it’s like living within and raising families in such a beautiful place.
results.description: Have you ever wondered what it’s like to live and work in a National Park? Cape Conran Coastal Park consists of 11,700 hectares of pristine coastal wilderness. results.title: The Swifts Creek Bush Nursing Centre
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: The small country town of Swifts Creek has had a bush nursing service since 1918 when staff were originally travelling on horseback. These days the bush nurse Sue Carroll visits patients in a 4WD and understands the importance of providing medical care to locals that are often isolated and unable to travel to the Omeo Hospital. Whether it’s farmers in need of wound management, children with the measles or victims of car accidents, Carroll is usually the first person on the scene. Part nurse, part social worker, all legend; Carroll and the staff at the Swifts Creek Bush Nursing Centre provide a vital 24/7 service to not only the local community but the wider surrounding regional area.

results.title: Respect and Belonging
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Learn about the Lake Tyres Indigenous community and the interesting life of elder; Aunty Phyllis Andy. As a respected Elder, pastor and community health worker, Aunty Phyllis Andy feels a strong connection not only to the land but the people that live within it. She understands the importance of connecting with the next generation and uses storytelling to pass on respect and culture to the young indigenous people of her community.

results.title: Paddle Steamer Curlip
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Join a group of passionate volunteers as they describe the trials, tribulations and joys of building and running a paddle steamer. From the initial planning in 2002, a group of Orbost locals built the PS Curlip II as part of a community project. After 16,000 hours of voluntary labour the paddle steamer was launched and continues in 2013 to transport tourists in and around the various waterways of East Gippsland. Members of the PS Curlip Committee talk about the history, their involvement and the future of the much-loved paddle steamer.
